page.title: 02OLD R'WAY LINE, DRAYTON
page.content: Part of the{Midland and Great {Northern Railway,}Drayton station was opened in{1882.}The station employed 6 or 7 local people.There was a waiting room,ticket office and manager's office,as well as some goods sheds and a signal box.Along with general freight, the trains carried locally-made bricks,and paper from the mill at Taverham. The station closed in{1952,}and in 1965 rebuilding took place, converting the area into a small {industrial park.}Some of the original buildings are still standing. The railway is now an attractive {foot and bridle path,}part of which is a nature trail.Now called Marriott's way, the path offers a pleasant walk through the Norfolk countryside.Locals enjoy this amenity,but would like a quick,easy route to Norwich.
